body:
http://mahkoh.github.io/style-guide/style-guide.xml

I've removed the C++ stuff from the Google guide and added our changes. The Google guide covers all Google projects but our guide only has to deal with Neovim. Therefore, and for the sake of consistency, I've used this chance to take some choice away. For example:
- Don't use /\* */ style comments
- Don't use MACRO_STYLE_NAMES for enumerators
- etc

Please read it carefully and voice your objections. 

Original guide: http://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/cppguide.xml

comment_data.body:
> When defining a function, parameter order is: inputs, then outputs.

Should we swap the parameters of functions like this:
`int mch_dirname(char_u *buf, int len)`
to
`int mch_dirname(int len, char_u *buf)`,
since `len` is actually a plain input parameter?

Looks a litte unconventional to me.

Nice work. Small note: The favicon shows a Google icon. I suggest changing or removing that in the XSL: https://mahkoh.github.io/style-guide/guide.xsl

Other notes:

> Use the // syntax only

Fine with me, but some people have started using javadoc-style `/** */` for doxygen. Seems [we can use other styles with doxygen](http://www.stack.nl/~dimitri/doxygen/manual/docblocks.html), but I guess we need a note about the preferred style in the style guide.

> We do not allow variable-length arrays or alloca()

Might want to provide a short justification/explanation. Also, I thought you wanted to use every C99 feature? :) One reason for avoiding VLAs: http://www.clarkcox.com/blog/2009/04/07/c99s-vlas-are-evil/

> When you have a boolean expression that is longer than the standard line length, keep operators at the start of the line

Glad to see this, but it will probably be controversial.

Another thing: some people like to align assignments, etc, like this:

```
int a         = 0;
int long_name = b;
```

I don't care one way or the other, but I do think it introduces extra churn and complicates the blame, when a new assignment is added/removed, and the entire block is re-aligned.

> Filenames should be all lowercase and can include underscores (_).
> Examples of acceptable file names:
> my__useful_file.c
> myusefulfile.c

I'd vote for mandatory replacement of spaces with underscores. Using both styles at the same time is far from being consistent and I personally think the first option is more readable.

@justinmk:

> The favicon shows a Google icon

Good catch. Do we have a favicon sized file with the new logo?

> doxygen

I like `///` better than `//!`. What do you think?

> Might want to provide a short justification/explanation. (VLAs)

I've removed the justifications from the Google version to keep the guide short so that people are more likely to read all of it. Regarding VLAs: I've no strong feelings either way.

---

There is also the copyright issue: Can we just copy parts of the Google style guide?

> Do we have a favicon sized file with the new logo?

I believe @jasonlong or @cweagans is working on that for the website.

> removed the justifications from the Google version

Oh, maybe just a link to [the Google version then](http://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/cppguide.xml?showone=Variable-Length_Arrays_and_alloca__#Variable-Length_Arrays_and_alloca__). But the explanation is short enough to include, plus the "reveal" buttons hide the information, anyways.

> I like /// better than //!. What do you think?

Agreed.
Once @jasonlong provides the image assets, I'll put the favicon on the website. Keep an eye there for changes!

Great work on this, @mahkoh. Here are some of my comments and questions:

**Doxygen**

I am also in favor of switching to `//` for comments in general and using `///` with `@annotation` for Doxygen.

**Aligning variable assignments**

I agree with @justinmk that we should disallow this due to the code churn it causes.

**Keeping logical operators at the beginning of the line when splitting**

I personally prefer keeping them at the end of the line because to me, it is easier to read with the terms of the expressions lined up, but since the Google style guide says that either is fine and since the Vim codebase has more instances of keeping them at the beginning, let's go with that.

**Don't use MACRO_STYLE_NAMES for enumerators**

Yes please. :) Glad to see this.

**Macros vs Inline functions**

I noticed you removed the section on inline functions. There are currently a significant number of macros. Are we allowing macros then?

**The #define Guard**

For header files in subdirectories, I think the `#define` guard should contain the subdirectory name as well since it is possible for a header file in a subdirectory to have the same file name as a different header file in another directory. For example, if we decide to move the ex-specific files under an `ex` subdirectory, then the header guard for `ex/eval.h` would be `#define NEOVIM_EX_EVAL_H`.
Great job @mahkoh

@davidzchen:

> I personally prefer keeping them at the end of the line because to me, it is easier to read with the terms of the expressions lined up

```
if (   aaaaaaaaa
    && bbbbbbbbbbbbbbb
    && cccc
    && dddddddddd)
```

Might work. I'm more concerned about the readability of mixed && and || statements. Those braces are sometimes hard to catch. Maybe something like

```
if (   aaaaaaaaa
    && (   bbbbbbbbbbbbbbb
        || cccc)
    && dddddddddd)
```

If that's not too fancy.

> Are we allowing macros then?

Macros are much more important in C than C++ and the Google version in certainly influenced by that. 

Here is one important difference between inline functions in C and C++: `inline` in C++ means that the function will always be inlined by the compiler. This is not the case in C. In that sense `inline` in C++ is much closer to macros.

> For header files in subdirectories

I didn't realize that we had those. I'll fix it.

@commonquail:

> which compilers will happily ignore

Looks like you are right. I don't know where I picked that up.

> I know string handling has been discussed elsewhere

That might work for strings but creating a new type for every single type that's used in array form is completely unidiomatic. We should all forget that I mistakenly included that part in my first version :)

> There is also the copyright issue: Can we just copy parts of the Google style guide?

@mahkoh The Google style guides are dual-licensed under perl/GPL : https://code.google.com/p/google-styleguide/

@mahkoh If we are putting operators on the left, let's just not add extra spaces to align the terms. I think that tends to hamper readability more. I'd be fine with having operators on the left as long as we are consistent.

Revision 2 is up.

New sections:
- Copyright
- Function declarations

Removed sections:
- Function parameter ordering

Modified sections:
- The #define Guard
- Constants in headers
- Variable length arrays
- Postincrement and Postdecrement
- File Names
- Function Names
- Comments
- Comment Style
- File Comments
- Struct Comments
- Function Comments
- Variable Comments
- Horizontal Whitespace

Sections that need attention:
- File Comments
- Variable Names

> Of the built-in integer types only use char, int, uint8_t, int8_t, uint16_t, int16_t, uint32_t, int32_t, uint64_t, int64_t, uintmax_t, intmax_t, size_t, ssize_t, uintptr_t, intptr_t, and ptrdiff_t. 

Why no `[u]int_least32_t`? If there is a bitflag variable where the highest flag is at 25 bit it does not really matter whether it will be represented using 32-bit, 64-bit or whatever integer, so the compiler can do more optimizations. I also do not see `bool` type, is it accepted/preferred/declined? I am not entirely sure that `bool` type fall into “built-in integer type” category.

From #341:
- Add note about not adding spaces after casts.
- Add note about not aligning line splices (`\`'s) for macros.

Is there a particular reason why we are only allowing postfix `i++` and rather than prefix `++i`?

According to the Google style guide, the rationale for choosing prefix increment/decrement is:

> When the return value is ignored, the "pre" form (++i) is never less efficient than the "post" form (i++), and is often more efficient. This is because post-increment (or decrement) requires a copy of i to be made, which is the value of the expression. If i is an iterator or other non-scalar type, copying i could be expensive. Since the two types of increment behave the same when the value is ignored, why not just always pre-increment?

Are you saying that this is solely a property of C++ compilers and not C compilers?

@davidzchen: It also says

> For simple scalar (non-object) values there is no reason to prefer one form and we allow either.
Ah, I missed the "If i is an iterator or other non-scalar type" part. That is fair.

A few more notes from #341:
- Make note about no spaces after opening brace for initializer lists more explicit.
- Make note about splitting the line in a params list only when the next param cannot fit on the current line.
- Add use of preincrement as a statement in a for-loop as a "bad" example in postincrement/postdecrement. Currently, it looks like preincrement/predecrement is only disallowed when used in a standalone statement.

@ZyX-I:

```
if ((var = func()) == NULL)
    return FAIL;
```

I also prefer this style. How do other people feel about this?

```
[u]int_least32_t
```

I don't think these types make a lot of sense on the platforms Neovim targets.

> I am not entirely sure that bool type fall into “built-in integer type” category.

Not for me.

@davidzchen:

> Make note about no spaces after opening brace for initializer lists more explicit.

You seem to want them, do you not? I don't see why this can't be discussed. In some cases, such as long nested arrays, having spaces is more readable.

---

I'll post a third revision this evening.

Reminder: 

> Sections that need attention:
> - File Comments
> - Variable Names

> ```
> if ((var = func()) == NULL)
>    return FAIL;
> ```
> 
> I also prefer this style. How do other people feel about this?

Personally, I dislike assignments in statement like this.  I'd rather it be broken out separately.  That's just my opinion though.

> Prefer
> 
> ```
> if ((x = f()) != A)
> ```
> 
> if x is only used in the block following the if.

I'm just not there on this.  To me, it's much better to assign `x` before the conditional.

> Prefer
> 
> ```
> while ((x = f()) != A)
> ```

I have to admit, I'm on the edge for this one.  I like that it removes the duplication, and it's even less redundant than a for-loop.  Though a for-loop reads better to me:

```
for (x = f(); x != A; x = f()) {
    ...
}
```

In the end, I don't think we should focus on getting the density so up that we lose readability.  As a person who has spent the last 13 years of their life as a consultant and reading other people's code (and lots of it), I still dislike the assignment in the conditional.

But, my opinion isn't the only one that counts here. :-)
Looks like we need a vote here.

@jszakmeister I believe that expressions in the form of:

``` C
if ((x = f()) != A)
```

and 

``` C
while ((x = f()) != A)
```

are idiomatic in C but perhaps not in other languages, though certain languages like Go have a similar pattern:

``` Go
if x := f(); x != A
```

I think that assignments in conditionals should be allowed as long as they are reasonable, which we can define as fitting under 80 characters.

@mahkoh I think I prefer adding spaces after braces for initializer lists. It is more readable in either case.

`if ((var1 = func1()) != NULL && a > b && (var2 = func2()) != NULL) {` looks not very reasonable to me.
If you are searching for the assignments of `var1` or `var2`, you have to evaluate the whole condition. Even worse, you'll probably end up checking the conditional if you're actually searching for another `var3`.
I'm against assignments in conditionals. But if we allow them, I'd at least hope, that we don't allow to combine them. In my opinion it should then be the only expression in the conditional.
@lslah Agreed. That would be one case where it would not be reasonable. I think we should limit the use of an assignment in the conditional when that is the only expression in the statement.

Another note: There are many instances where several local variables are declared on the same line:

``` C
UINT32_T temp, xs = *p_xl, xr = *p_xr;
```

I think this should be disallowed and that each variable needs to be declared and/or initialized on its separate line because this hinders readability.

Revision 3 is up.

New sections:
- Parting Words
- Booleans
- Variable declarations

Modified sections:
- Postincrement and Postdecrement
- File Comments
- Function Declarations and Definitions
- Braced Initializer Lists
- Horizontal Whitespace

---

Since nobody seems to care atm I've decided that there won't be any kind of license or copyright note inside the c and h files and that global variables will be prefixed with g_.

> Since nobody seems to care atm I've decided that there won't be any kind of license or copyright note inside the c and h files

Legally, it doesn't matter, so it's just noise.

Good job, @mahkoh.

A few comments:

**Horizontal Whitespace**

The example for braced initializer lists here needs spaces between the braces to be consistent with the rule in the Braced Initializer Lists section.

**Function Declarations and Definitions**

Can we specify that function declarations that are public must be in the header file and that functions that are private to the file must all have forward declarations at the beginning of the file after the `#include`s.

**Global Variables**

`g_gobal_variable` is fine with me, though we should gradually disallow global state.

> Every function must have a declaration separate from its definition.
> 
> ```
> static void f(void);
> 
> static void f(void)
> {
>   ...
> }
> ```

I think this isn't a good idea--at least in this example.  Much better to arrange the file that the required functions are defined before they're needed.  It cuts down on some redundancy and it's one less place to tweak when the signature changes.

@jszakmeister: See http://mahkoh.github.io/style-guide/style-guide.xml?showone=Function_Comments#Function_Comments

To keep these things separated for static functions we'll need separate declarations and definitions. To keep everything consistent we demand separate declarations and definitions.

> @jszakmeister I believe that expressions in the form of:
> 
> ```
> if ((x = f()) != A)
> ```
> 
> and
> 
> ```
> while ((x = f()) != A)
> ```
> 
> are idiomatic in C but perhaps not in other languages, though certain languages like Go have a similar pattern:

@davidzchen I'd hardly call it idiomatic.  Assignments in conditionals have been debated for as long as I can remember--for at least the 20+ years since I started C programming.

I'll concede that the second form has a nice benefit of removing a bit of redundancy.  But the saving of one line in the first form is hardly worth it, IMHO.

> To keep these things separated for static functions we'll need separate declarations and definitions. To keep everything consistent we demand separate declarations and definitions.

No offense, but I still think it's unnecessary redundancy.  There's no reason you can put the doc string with the static function definition.  I think only public functions should have it elsewhere--in the header, where other devs are more likely to read it.  I think the inconsistency is worth removing the redundancy, IMHO.

I have to admit I'm not fan of banning the use of `/* ... */` style comments either, nor preferring the `//` and `///` style comments.  The `/* ... */` and `/** ... */` style for comments makes wrapping much easier if you need to reflow a paragraph--as long as you leave of the leading `*` on the lines.

All that said, I'm glad you and others are spending time trying to work out the details.  In the end, it will make for a much cleaner code base (assuming we stick to it).

One small pet peeve: coding standards often seem like a license to nitpick.  So if I could put a suggestion out there, it would be to strive to find an actual bug in code review and not focus solely on style.  Style is important, and we want to get it right, but I've found that many teams stop there and I think we should strive to go a bit further as a community.

> There's no reason you can put the doc string with the static function definition.

Post an example.

> The /\* ... _/ and /_\* ... */ style for comments makes wrapping much easier if you need to reflow a paragraph

```
:h gq
```

> One small pet peeve: coding standards often seem like a license to nitpick. So if I could put a suggestion out there, it would be to strive to find an actual bug in code review and not focus solely on style.

I don't like what you're trying to imply here. If anything I want to get this out of the way so that I can continue to work on `clint.py`. @ZyX-I is working on his vim2lua compiler, @lslah is working on removing dead code. Sure, this issue is bikeshedding, but that doesn't mean that it's blocking the rest of the project.

@jszakmeister:

> Post an example.

That's not what I'm asking for. An example where there is no separate declaration and definition, with Doxygen docs, with implementation details not part of the Doxygen.

> Do you have something setup so that you get better results?

```
set comments=:///,://
```

> That's not what I'm asking for. An example where there is no separate declaration and definition, with Doxygen docs, with implementation details not part of the Doxygen.

@mahkoh What's wrong with putting the implementation details _in the function_, where they probably belong?  If a developer needs to know more, and it doesn't make sense to put in the function itself, then doesn't it belong in the Doxygen comment?

FWIW, I'm not sure that static functions should require Doxygen comments.  I tend to think of Doxygen as documentation of a public API, and static functions are not part of that.  _shrug_

> ```
> set comments=:///,://
> ```

Thanks.

> What's wrong with putting the implementation details in the function, where they probably belong?

That's a different issue. The Google version chose that format in http://mahkoh.github.io/style-guide/style-guide.xml?showone=Function_Comments#Function_Comments . Are you now arguing against that idea in general and not just for static functions?

> I'm not sure that static functions should require Doxygen comments.

I think they should. It makes browsing the source much easier.

> That's a different issue. The Google version chose that format in http://mahkoh.github.io/style-guide/style-guide.xml?showone=Function_Comments#Function_Comments . Are you now arguing against that idea in general and not just for static functions?

I don't see that it is.  And no, just for static functions.  I don't think you need a separate declaration and documentation just to have consistency with the public functions.  If you guys want it, and think it's a great idea, then great.  I'll follow whatever standard is chosen.  I just don't think the consistency is worth the redundancy for static functions, that is all.

> I think they should. It makes browsing the source much easier.

Fair enough.  I've always found it easier to read source by reading the source--in particular, using ctags and the ability to jump into and out of functions.

I find the nicest way to lay out code is to (in general) put higher level functions above lower level. I don't agree with a style that restricts the order in which you can write functions.

One other thing I'd like to see is to disallow yoda conditions. Prefer `if (x == 1)` to `if (1 == x)`
I'll keep this open for another 24 hours. Then I'll post a final version and @tarruda gets to decide if he wants any changes. And then we're done.

I'll make one last proposal.

---

Use only spaces, and indent **4** spaces at a time. Do not use tabs in your code.

---

The very simple reason: I have poor vision and deeper indentation = better readability.

Before you reply please consider that the original vim source also uses 4 spaces. (ftp://ftp.vim.org/pub/vim/unix/vim-7.4.tar.bz2)
@mahkoh I would _love_ to see that.  I've used two spaces in the past, and it's just too small, IMHO.

I have gotten used to 2 spaces and prefer using 2 spaces for certain languages including C and C++, but in this case, I would be fine with using 4 spaces, especially since having gone through some of the code, using a wider indentations will give us more encouragement to break up some of the functions that nest very deeply.

I agree with @mahkoh in objecting to 2 space indentation. I suggest a tab-space combo called [smart tabs](http://www.emacswiki.org/SmartTabs). Use tabs for _indentation_ and spaces for _alignment_. This way developers can set their own tab widths **and** guarantee consistent alignment, the best of both worlds :smile:

Here's an example using GNU's alignment style and this kind of indentation:

``` c
int main (int argc, char** argv) {
    mode = ((inmode[j] == VOIDmode
             || (GET_MODE_SIZE (outmode[j]) > GET_MODE_SIZE (inmode[j])))
            ? outmode[j] : inmode[j]);
}
```

Lines 2, 3, and 4 are indented with one tab each since they are at the 1st indentation level, and lines 3 and 4 further aligned with spaces.

EDIT: misread @mahkoh's post :tongue: and edited to make more sense

@cbarrick I appreciate the suggestion, but I have worked on projects that use tabs for indentation and spaces for alignment _and_ allowing developers to set their own tab widths (unlike the Linux kernel style, which mandates that tabs be 8 spaces wide), and virtually every time, correcting indentation was a headache because someone forgets to only tab once and align or somebody's editor auto-aligned with tabs rather than spaces.

We have already gone through the process of selecting a coding style (#104), for which indentation style was huge deciding factor, and are already in the process of re-formatting a significant number of files (#311). I think changing the indent style to 4 spaces is passable, but I am strongly against introducing tabs at this point.
@davidzchen There was no smart tabs option in the vote, though, so you could make an argument that the vote was skewed.

@davidzchen:

> the overwhelming support (see results tally) was for the three options that used 2 spaces for indentation

I've already made my argument for 4 spaces above and I think it's strong enough to stand on its own but since you're making this argument I think I should mention that the previous vote might have been screwed by @tarruda's decision to 2 space indent the code before uploading the source to github.

> At this point, I don't have much appetite for dragging on the deliberation for trying to decide on a coding style longer since we have already spent more than a week on it.

This issue is done in about 4 hours no matter what. After that @tarruda gets to make the final decisions.

@mahkoh As I mentioned in my previous comment, I personally would be fine with using 4 spaces, but I can't speak for other project contributors. No matter what we decide on, somebody will be unhappy with some style requirement because everybody has different personal tastes.

I'll leave it up to @tarruda to have the final say. I have halted my reformatting work until this is finalized. Let's finalize the style guide soon so that we can focus on making Neovim great.

I've uploaded a new version that only fixes a typo. 

@tarruda: Here are the open questions you have to address:
- Separate declaration and definition
- `if ((x = f()))` etc
- 4 space indentation
- yoda conditions

Please reread the thread and guide asap and post your decisions.

Since one of the primary languages is indent-based (moonscript) I strongly prefer 4 spaces. Smart tabs would be better if somebody can say how to automatically use them and how to force others do the same (take this as "no smart tabs").

Yoda conditions look unnatural. And I do not remember last time I had any problems with accident assignment that were not caught by compiler (except for one time where I have written assignment in conditional break in the debugger, but this cannot be fixed by any code style or compiler warnings).

12.03.14, 22:05, "mahkoh" notifications@github.com":

> I've uploaded a new version that only fixes a typo. 
> @tarruda: Here are the open questions you have to address:Separate declaration and definitionif ((x = f())) etc4 space indentationyoda conditions
> Please reread the thread and guide asap and post your decisions.
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

> nobody proposed smart tabs

I was pretty sure I did. But if we want to paint the bikeshed with 2-space paint, then so be it. This isn't worth arguing about.

@mahkoh  Here's my decision:
- separate declaration and definitions of static functions, with the declarations before any public function and the definitions after all the public functions(static function declarations -> public functions -> static function definitions).
- at most one assignment in `if` or `while`, if more than one is needed then move everything out of the boolean expression(no `ifs` such as the example given by @lslah, that is very unreadable)
- 2 spaces indent
- no yoda conditions

I also want to be consistent regarding comments. Personally I prefer C++ comments, but only if it's possible to convert the old comments automatically. If not let's stick to C comments.
Final version is up. Now I need someone to proofread it both grammatically and logically.

Under Integer Types in "Note that the sign of char is implementation defined.": s/sign/signedness/
Under Conditions in "Use at most one assignment pre condition": s/pre/per/
There's some c++ code under the sizeof section. (I don't think it matters though)
The code under Struct Comments demonstrates bad naming conventions from vim (e.g., win_T)
Under Horizontal Whitespace a comment says: "No spaces inside braces for braced-init-list." which is out of date.

Other typos: allign -> align, clearity -> clarity
The comment style says to use "//" syntax only, but many of the examples that follow use "///".
Fixed. If that's all then I'll leave the rest to someone with commit access.

Under **Horizontal Whitespace** -> **General**:
Is the function `f` example correct/needed (the opening curly brace of function `f` should be on the next line)?
fixed
@mahkoh https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-style also needs the link updated.

Good job on this, @mahkoh.

One more note: for splitting lines in boolean expressions, I think there should be a note that the operator at the beginning of the line should be lined up with the beginning of its first operand. Otherwise, it would be difficult to read.

Under **Formatting** -> **Function Declarations and Definitions** -> **Some points to note**:
The following entry should not be needed anymore:
- There should be a space between the close parenthesis and the open curly brace.
Updated section about global variables.
Updated section regarding formatting of function declarations and definitions.
@mahkoh "Only use enum constants in header files. Do not use macros." This is not very clear to me. I can still add `enum` constants in `.c` files, right?
"In header files, only use enum constants".
However, you are allowed to define a macro that holds the same value as a non-enum constant (defined in the same header) if the value of the constant represents the size of an array.

Enums for flags (most of header numeric #defines are flags) is an abusal of enum meaning. And, by the way, there is a file that uses long for flags.

22.03.14, 06:42, "mahkoh" notifications@github.com":

> However, you are allowed to define a macro that holds the same value as a non-enum constant (defined in the same header) if the value of the constant represents the size of an array.
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

## 

Sent from Yandex.Mail for mobile: http://m.ya.ru/ymail

@mahkoh Agree with @ZyX-l. The style guide should recommend `const` where
it makes more sense.

On Sat, Mar 22, 2014 at 10:21 PM, ZyX-I notifications@github.com wrote:

> Enums for flags (most of header numeric #defines are flags) is an abusal
> of enum meaning. And, by the way, there is a file that uses long for flags.
> 
> 22.03.14, 06:42, "mahkoh" notifications@github.com":
> 
> > However, you are allowed to define a macro that holds the same value as
> > a non-enum constant (defined in the same header) if the value of the
> > 
> > ## constant represents the size of an array.
> > 
> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Sent from Yandex.Mail for mobile: http://m.ya.ru/ymail
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/323#issuecomment-38370130
> .
Clarified the section regarding constants.

title: Style guide
